PBSAI assumes baseline enterprise security capabilities and encodes key systems security techniques including analytic monitoring, coordinated defense, and adaptive response. A distinctive feature is the use of shared context envelopes and structured output contracts between agent families, providing a formal mechanism for maintaining traceability, provenance, and human-in-the-loop guarantees across domains.

The paper demonstrates practical application in enterprise Security Operations Center (SOC) and hyperscale defensive environments, showing how the architecture maps to NIST AI RMF functions. This makes it one of the few academic works that bridges the gap between high-level AI governance frameworks and concrete, implementable enterprise architectures.

Notable Quotes

"Enterprises are rapidly deploying large language models, retrieval augmented generation pipelines, and tool-using agents into production on shared high-performance computing clusters, and these systems function as AI estates: socio-technical systems spanning models, agents, data pipelines, security tooling, human workflows, and hyperscale infrastructure."

"Existing governance and security frameworks, including the NIST AI Risk Management Framework and systems security engineering guidance, do not provide implementable architectures for multi-agent, AI-enabled cyber defense."

Relevance to Topic

This paper is highly relevant as it provides one of the most detailed and rigorous reference architectures for AI governance at the enterprise level. The twelve-domain taxonomy and bounded agent family model offer a concrete architectural pattern for organizations trying to operationalize AI governance. The explicit NIST AI RMF alignment and the concept of "AI estates" as socio-technical systems are directly applicable to enterprise architecture practice. The paper bridges the gap between governance frameworks and implementable architecture -- exactly the intersection that EA for AI needs to address.

sources.title: The Enterprise IT Overhaul: Architecting Your Stack for the Agentic AI Era
sources.author: CIO.com
sources.body_html:
Key Takeaways

  • The fundamental architectural shift for agentic AI is moving from synchronous, tightly coupled connections to event-driven architecture (EDA)
  • An event-driven architecture built on message brokers like Apache Kafka decouples agents from each other and from core enterprise systems
  • The data streaming and messaging backbone becomes the primary agent orchestration layer, requiring investment to handle semantic complexity and volume of agent-to-agent communication
  • Organizations need to create an "agent tier" in their enterprise architecture comprising cognitive AI for reasoning capabilities and autonomous orchestration systems
  • Traditional REST API calls to monolithic systems (ERP, CRM) create bottlenecks for autonomous agents
  • "If 2025 was about the brain (the LLM), 2026 must be about the nervous system"

Summary

This CIO.com article provides a practical architectural blueprint for enterprises preparing their technology stacks for the agentic AI era. The central argument is that agentic AI -- autonomous systems capable of reasoning, planning, and executing multi-step tasks across the enterprise -- requires a fundamental rethinking of enterprise architecture, not incremental API additions.

The article identifies event-driven architecture as the foundational shift required. Traditional synchronous, tightly coupled integration patterns (typical REST API calls to monolithic ERP and CRM systems) create bottlenecks when agents need to operate autonomously. Instead, organizations should adopt asynchronous, event-driven architectures where agents interact with a message bus (like Apache Kafka or Amazon EventBridge) rather than making direct, blocking calls to legacy databases. This allows for long-running tasks where agents can trigger actions and resume when events are published back.

A key architectural concept introduced is the "agent tier" -- a new layer in the enterprise architecture comprising cognitive AI for reasoning capabilities and autonomous orchestration systems that trigger appropriate applications. This represents a significant evolution of traditional enterprise architecture layering models, adding an intelligent orchestration layer between business processes and underlying systems.

Notable Quotes

"If 2025 was about the brain (the LLM), 2026 must be about the nervous system."

"The traditional approach to integrating new tools -- a simple REST API call to a monolithic system like your ERP or CRM -- is a bottleneck for autonomous agents."

"An event-driven architecture, typically built on a message broker like Kafka, decouples agents from one another and from your core systems."

Relevance to Topic

This article provides concrete, actionable architectural guidance for the technology architecture domain of EA for AI. The concept of an "agent tier" as a new enterprise architecture layer directly extends traditional EA layering models (like TOGAF's architecture domains). The emphasis on event-driven architecture as a prerequisite for agentic AI deployment offers a specific technical pattern that enterprise architects can adopt. The "brain vs. nervous system" framing effectively communicates that AI infrastructure is as important as AI models themselves.

sources.title: Enterprise Architecture as a Dynamic Capability for Scalable and Sustainable Generative AI Adoption: Bridging Innovation and Governance in Large Organisations
sources.author: Alexander Ettinger
sources.body_html:
Key Takeaways

  • Theorizes Enterprise Architecture Management (EAM) as a dynamic capability (sensing, seizing, transforming) that enables scalable and sustainable GenAI adoption
  • Based on systematic literature review and qualitative analysis of 16 semi-structured expert interviews using the Gioia methodology
  • Identifies critical enablers and barriers to GenAI adoption across industries
  • Reveals key limitations in existing EA frameworks (particularly TOGAF) -- their inability to fully address unique GenAI requirements including ethical governance, lifecycle artifacts, and the speed of AI-driven transformation
  • Proposes extensions to EA frameworks to meet the needs of automation, AI, and digital governance
  • Finds that organizations with clean, modular architectures can leverage GenAI to accelerate development 30-50%, while those with legacy systems are trapped in governance cycles too slow to capture value
  • Identifies "the acceleration paradox": architectural technical debt from rapid GenAI innovation creates a self-reinforcing gap between leaders and laggards

Summary

This academic paper examines how Enterprise Architecture Management can serve as a dynamic capability for organizations seeking to adopt Generative AI at scale. Using the dynamic capabilities framework (sensing, seizing, transforming), the research investigates how EAM can enhance strategic alignment, governance frameworks, and organizational agility for GenAI adoption. The study is grounded in both a systematic literature review and 16 semi-structured interviews with industry experts, analyzed using the Gioia methodology.

The paper reveals an important tension: while EA frameworks like TOGAF provide valuable governance structures, they lack the agility, ethical governance mechanisms, and lifecycle artifacts needed for AI-driven transformation. The research identifies what it calls "the acceleration paradox" -- organizations with clean, modular architectures can leverage GenAI to accelerate development by 30-50%, but those navigating legacy systems find themselves trapped in ADM cycles that are too slow to capture value before the next wave of AI innovation renders their architectural decisions obsolete. This creates a widening gap between architectural leaders and laggards.

Key findings include the need to tailor EA frameworks to GenAI-specific challenges such as low data governance maturity, the balance between innovation and compliance, and the requirement for new architectural patterns that accommodate rapid experimentation alongside enterprise-grade governance. The paper proposes specific extensions to existing frameworks to bridge these gaps.

Notable Quotes

"Organizations with clean, modular architectures can leverage GenAI to accelerate development 30-50%, but those navigating legacy systems find themselves trapped in ADM cycles that are too slow to capture value before the next wave of AI innovation renders their architecture decisions obsolete."

"TOGAF apparently lacks the agility, ethical governance, and lifecycle artifacts required for AI-driven transformation."

"The architectural technical debt accumulating from rapid GenAI innovation creates what researchers call 'the acceleration paradox.'"

Relevance to Topic

This paper is directly at the heart of the EA for AI research topic. It provides academic rigor and expert interview data to validate the hypothesis that traditional EA frameworks need significant adaptation for AI adoption. The dynamic capabilities lens (sensing, seizing, transforming) offers a theoretical framework for understanding how EA creates value in the AI context. The identification of the "acceleration paradox" and the 30-50% development acceleration for architecturally mature organizations provides both a cautionary tale and an aspirational target. The proposed TOGAF extensions offer a concrete path forward for framework evolution.

sources.title: The Paradox of Governance: When TOGAF's Architecture Development Method Meets GenAI's Velocity
sources.author: Praveen Mittal
sources.body_html:
Key Takeaways

  • TOGAF's ADM was designed for a world where change happened in measured cycles, with ten phases presuming time for deliberation, stakeholder workshops, documentation cycles, and human decision checkpoints
  • GenAI usage across businesses jumped from 33% to 78% in a single year, fundamentally invalidating the ADM's assumption of measured change cycles
  • The velocity of technological change invalidates the underlying assumptions of traditional governance frameworks
  • Organizations successfully integrating TOGAF with GenAI are radically adapting the ADM -- collapsing phases, running them in parallel, and treating the framework as principles rather than process
  • Architectural technical debt from rapid GenAI innovation creates the "acceleration paradox" where slow governance cycles prevent organizations from capturing value
  • Proposes that EA frameworks need to evolve from sequential process-driven approaches to principle-based, parallel-execution models for AI contexts

Summary

This article examines the fundamental tension between TOGAF's Architecture Development Method and the velocity of generative AI adoption in enterprises. The author argues that the ADM's ten phases -- designed with the assumption that architectural change happens in deliberate, measured cycles with time for stakeholder workshops, documentation, and review -- are fundamentally misaligned with the speed at which GenAI transforms business capabilities.

The article documents how GenAI adoption has accelerated from 33% to 78% of businesses in a single year, and how AI applications now move from concept to production in weeks rather than quarters. This speed creates what the author calls a governance paradox: the very frameworks designed to ensure sound architectural decisions become impediments to capturing value from AI, as architectural decisions become obsolete before governance cycles complete.

However, the article is not an argument for abandoning governance. Instead, it examines how leading organizations are adapting TOGAF by collapsing ADM phases, running phases in parallel rather than sequentially, and treating the framework as a set of principles rather than a rigid process. This pragmatic adaptation preserves the governance intent while accommodating the velocity of AI innovation.

Notable Quotes

"TOGAF's ADM was architected for a world where change happened in measured cycles, with ten phases presuming time for deliberation, stakeholder workshops, documentation cycles, and human decision checkpoints."

"GenAI usage across businesses jumped from 33% to 78% in a single year."

"Organizations successfully integrating TOGAF with GenAI are those that radically adapt the ADM -- collapsing phases, running them in parallel rather than sequence, and treating the framework as principles rather than process."

Relevance to Topic

This article directly addresses one of the most important questions in EA for AI: how should traditional EA frameworks adapt to accommodate the speed of AI innovation? The identification of the governance paradox -- where governance frameworks designed for sound decisions become barriers to value capture -- is a critical insight for enterprise architects. The practical adaptation strategies (collapsing phases, parallel execution, principle-based approach) offer actionable guidance for organizations trying to maintain governance discipline while enabling AI agility.

sources.title: The Open Group AI Initiatives and Enterprise Architecture Practitioners Conference 2026
sources.author: The Open Group
sources.body_html:
Key Takeaways

  • The Open Group is positioning itself as a "trusted facilitator for the future of professional practice standards in the context of AI-powered technologies"
  • The Open Group Eagle AI Assistant is a new AI tool that provides real-time guidance aligned with Open Group standards, with citation tracking for transparency and traceability
  • The February 2026 EA Practitioners Conference in London featured dedicated workshops on "AI in the Enterprise -- Making Autonomous Systems into Reliable Business Tools"
  • TOGAF 10 (10th Edition) is being extended through new Series Guides released annually, covering agility, digital strategy, business architecture, and cloud adoption
  • The Open Group is developing the ArchiMate Specification and Open Agile Architecture Standard alongside AI-focused standards
  • The organization is leveraging existing professional practices for those architecting and training AI models

Summary

The Open Group, the standards body behind TOGAF and ArchiMate, has launched multiple AI-related initiatives that signal how the enterprise architecture standards landscape is evolving to accommodate artificial intelligence. Central to these efforts is the positioning of The Open Group as a "trusted facilitator" for professional practice standards in the context of AI-powered technologies.

A flagship product of these initiatives is The Open Group Eagle AI Assistant, which uses large language model technology combined with Open Group standards to provide real-time, authoritative guidance for enterprise architects. The tool features citation tracking to ensure traceability to official sources, multilingual support for global accessibility, and persona-based interactions tailored for different user roles (enterprise architects, trainers, organizational leaders). This represents an interesting case of "eating your own cooking" -- using AI to help practitioners apply architecture standards more effectively.

At the February 2026 Enterprise Architecture Practitioners Conference in London, workshops focused specifically on making autonomous AI systems reliable business tools.
